I M A G I N E

European Constitutional Imaginaries

Utopias, Ideologies and the Other

  • people

  • imagine loud

forthcoming

10_12_2020

Why read The Transformation of Europe today? On the limits of a liberal constitutional imaginary by Jan Komárek

May help us understand the limits of liberal constitutional imaginary, on which Transformation builds and which it helped to establish in the 1990s. Now, when ‘Western liberalism’ is on retreat, such critical reading may be indispensable for those who look for alternatives.

>

letters

10_12_2020

Jan Komárek: Political economy in the European constitutional imaginary – moving beyond Fiesole

This short reflection was published as a contribution to an online symposium at Verfassungsblog on Poul F. Kjær (ed), The law of political economy: Transformations in the function of law (CUP 2020).

video

10_12_2020

Interview With Petr Agha

Welcome to the first podcast brought to you by the IMAGINE Project, run by Professor Jan Komarek and hosted at the iCourts Centre of Excellence for International Courts, University of Copenhagen. IMAGINE works on the Intellectual History of European Constitutional Imaginaries. Today, we will talk to Jan Komarek about his project. What is it that Jan wants to find out about the EU and its constitutional law? What does Joseph Weiler, one of the most famous and influential theorists of European Union constitutional law, have to do with Jan’s project? Is Jan critical towards the current paradigm of European Union law and its internal market? Is he critical about the role of the Court of Justice, traditionally depicted as a constitutional engine of European integration? Does he think that the constitutional vocabulary of the EU could and should be different? And, last but not least, can Karl Marx and political economy tell us something about EU law and its internal market today?

>

This project has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement No 803163) and is hosted by the University of Copenhagen.
